intro: Anacampseros albicans, commonly known as the white sandplant, is a succulent native to the arid regions of South Africa. It belongs to the family Aizoaceae, which is characterized by its fleshy leaves and adaptations to dry environments. The plant has a rosette growth form, with thick, fleshy leaves that store water, allowing it to survive in harsh, drought-prone conditions. Its flowers are typically small and yellow, appearing in the spring, and it produces a distinctive, fluffy seed head. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and sensitive species, often found in sandy or gravelly soils.
